item.title: About
item.description: This is a “hello world” example website for the blogdown package. The theme was forked from @jrutheiser/hugo-lithium-theme and modified by Yihui Xie.

item.title: 1.1. The Tools of Microeconomics
item.description: Contents Overview Slides Preliminary Survey Overview An introduction to the course and the tools we use in microeconomics. Slides Lecture Slides Preliminary Survey Please take the preliminary survey on your math background. This will help us all have a productive course together.

item.title: 1.3 Optimization and the Budget Constraint - Class Notes
item.description: Contents Overview Slides Practice Problems Math Survey Math Review Thursday, January 23, 2020 Overview We begin with an overview of constrained optimization models and our first application, how individuals choose. Our primary focus will be people as consumers - how do they choose to spend their money and how do those choices change? While we will focus extensively on consumers making purchasing choices, do not think this is the only use of this type of model!

item.title: 1.3 Optimization and the Budget Constraint - Practice Problems
item.description: Download as PDF Answer Key You can get music via downloads (\(d\)) or concert tickets (\(t\)). You have $60 to spend each week, and the price of a download is $3 and the price of a concert ticket is $10. Put \(d\) on the horizontal axis and \(t\) on the vertical axis. 1 Write the equation for your budget constraint. 2 Solve this equation for \(t\), to express the equation of the line.

item.title: 1.3 Optimization and the Budget Constraint - Readings
item.description: Recommended Ch. 4.3 in Austan Goolsbee, Steven Levitt, and Chad SyversonMicroeconomics, 2nd ed. (USA: Worth Publishers, 2012). Now that we are picking up the intensity and working with some models (many will be new to you at first), I recommend looking at the textbook readings for each class. We are going a bit out of order in two ways. First, Goolsbee et. al start with a review of Supply and Demand in chapters 2-3, and don’t get to “Consumer Theory” (what we are starting now) until chapter 4.

item.title: 1.4 Preferences I: Indifference Curves - Class Notes
item.description: Contents Overview Slides Practice Problems Math Appendix Utility Functions and PMTs Tuesday, January 28, 2020 Overview We continue with our model of how individuals choose. Our focus for this class, and next, is what are people’s objectives? How can we operationalize their preferences in a meaningful way? Today we will discuss one tool - indifference curves - and start an explanation of utility and how we can model people as trying to “maximize” it (we will wrap that up in the next class).

item.title: 1.4 Preferences I: Indifference Curves - Readings
item.description: Recommended Ch. 4.1-4.2 in Austan Goolsbee, Steven Levitt, and Chad SyversonMicroeconomics, 2nd ed. (USA: Worth Publishers, 2012).

item.title: 1.5 Preferences II: Indifference Curves - MRS and Utility Functions
item.description: Recommended Ch. 4.1-4.2 in Austan Goolsbee, Steven Levitt, and Chad SyversonMicroeconomics, 2nd ed. (USA: Worth Publishers, 2012). This is the same reading as last class (we are taking two class periods to cover preferences).

item.title: 1.5 Preferences II: Indifference Curves - MRS and Utility Functions
item.description: Recommended Ch. 4.4-4.5 in Austan Goolsbee, Steven Levitt, and Chad SyversonMicroeconomics, 2nd ed. (USA: Worth Publishers, 2012).

item.title: 1.5 Preferences II: MRS and Marginal Utility - Class Notes
item.description: Contents Overview Slides Practice Problems Math Appendix Graphing Indifference Curves Utility Functions for Perfect Substitutes Utility Functions for Perfect Complements Cobb-Douglas Functions Thursday, January 30, 2020 Overview We continue with our model of how individuals choose. Our focus for this class is to wrap up what we mean by “maximizing utility” as a person’s objective. We will do some practice problems on understanding indifference curves and utility functions.

item.title: 1.5 Preferences II: MRS and Utility Functions - Practice Problems
item.description: Download as PDF Answer Key 1 For each question, draw an indifference curve relating the two objects (label it \(I_1\)). Draw and label a second curve that gives higher utility (label it \(I_2\)), and a third curve that gives lower utility (label it \(I_0\)). a. Oranges (a good) on the horizontal axis and Pollution (a bad) on the vertical axis. b. Pollution (a bad) on the horizontal axis and Soda (a good) on the vertical axis.

item.title: 1.6 Solving the Consumer's Problem - Class Notes
item.description: Contents Overview Slides Practice Problems Assignment: Problem Set 1 Math Appendix Solving the Constrained Optimization Problem with Calculus Thursday, February 6, 2020 Overview Today we put all of our tools together thus far to solve the consumer’s constrained optimization problem. To solve the problem the “traditional way” would be to use Lagrangian multipliers and calculus and solve for the first order conditions. We instead will find the solution by looking graphically, and use an algebraic rule that should make intuitive sense.

item.title: 1.6 Solving the Consumer's Problem - Practice Problems
item.description: Download as PDF Answer Key You can get utility from consuming Soda \((s)\) and Hot dogs \((h)\), according to the utility function: \[u(s,h)=\sqrt{sh}\] The marginal utilities are: \[\begin{align*} MU_s&=0.5s^{-0.5}h^{0.5} \\ MU_h&=0.5s^{0.5}h^{-0.5} \\ \end{align*}\] You have an income of $12, the price of Soda is $2, and the price of a Hot dog is $3. Put Soda on the horizontal axis and Hot dogs on the vertical axis.

item.title: 1.7 Building a Demand Function - Class Notes
item.description: Contents Overview Slides Practice Problems Assignments: Problem Sets 1, 2, and Exam 1 Tuesday, February 11, 2020 Overview Solving a single constrained optimum problem might be useful in certain contexts, but the dynamics of change are more interesting: how do people optimally respond to changes in constraints? The remaining few classes before Exam 1 are about how people respond to changes in prices and income. If we can describe this set of behaviors in an equation and graphically, it is the origin of a demand curve.

item.title: 1.7 Building a Demand Function - Practice Problems
item.description: Download as PDF Answer Key You can spend your income on apples and oranges. Apples currently cost $0.25 and oranges cost $0.50. When your income is $40, you buy 10 apples and 8 oranges. When your income increases to $80, you buy 12 apples and 6 oranges. 1. What type of good are apples (inferior, necessity, luxury)? 2. What type of good are oranges (inferior, necessity, or luxury)?

item.title: 1.7 Building a Demand Function - Readings
item.description: Recommended Ch. 5.1, 5.2, 5.4 in Austan Goolsbee, Steven Levitt, and Chad SyversonMicroeconomics, 2nd ed. (USA: Worth Publishers, 2012).

item.title: 1.8 Income and Substitution Effects - Class Notes
item.description: Contents Overview Slides Interactive Examples Practice Problems Assignments: Problem Set 1 is DUE and Problem Set 2 Math Appendix Example Demand Functions Cobb-Douglas Thursday, February 13, 2020 Overview Today we cover the third effect: the (own) price effect, aka the law of demand: how changes in a good’s (own) price affect quantity demanded for that good. We introduce the idea of demand functions, inverse demand functions, and a demand curve.

item.title: 1.8 Income and Substitution Effects - Readings
item.description: Recommended Ch. 2.2, 5.3 in Austan Goolsbee, Steven Levitt, and Chad SyversonMicroeconomics, 2nd ed. (USA: Worth Publishers, 2012).

item.title: 1.9 Price Elasticity - Class Notes
item.description: Contents Overview Slides Example Applications of Consumer Theory Models Practice Problems Assignments: Problem Set 1 Answers, Problem Set 2 Due Next Class, Exam 1 Tuesday, February 18, 2020 Overview Today we look at price elasticity of demand, and wrap up our Unit 1 on Consumer/Individual choice theory. A reminder, your second problem set is due next class; next class is our review session, and we will have Exam 1 on Tuesday October 1 (for Section 1 - TuTh) and Wednesday October 2 (for Section 2 - MW).

item.title: 1.9 Price Elasticity - Practice Problems
item.description: Download as PDF Answer Key The demand for monthly cell phone plans is given by: \[q_D = 50-0.5p\] 1. Write the inverse demand function. 2. Calculate the price elasticity of demand when the price is $10. Is this relatively elastic or inelastic? 3. Calculate the price elasticity of demand when the price is $70. Is this relatively elastic or inelastic? 4. At what price is demand unit elastic \((\epsilon=-1)\)?

item.title: 1.9 Price Elasticity - Readings
item.description: Recommended Ch. 2.2, 2.5, 5.5 in Austan Goolsbee, Steven Levitt, and Chad SyversonMicroeconomics, 2nd ed. (USA: Worth Publishers, 2012).

item.title: 2.1 Theory of the Firm - Class Notes
item.description: Contents Overview Slides Thursday, February 27, 2020 Overview Today we start looking on the supply side of the market for the next few weeks. You will ultimately see, we will use the same tools (and get basically the same results!) for studying producers (constrained optimization models) as we did for consumers. Sometimes, these models finally “click” for students the second time around, and production is often more intuitive than utility and consumption.

item.title: 2.1 Theory of the Firm - Readings
item.description: Recommended Ch. 6.1 in Austan Goolsbee, Steven Levitt, and Chad SyversonMicroeconomics, 2nd ed. (USA: Worth Publishers, 2012).

item.title: 2.2 Short Run and Long Run - Class Notes
item.description: Contents Overview Slides Appendix Solving the Firm’s Problem in One Step The Firm’s Supply and Demand Functions The Geometry of Short-Run Production The Relationship Between Marginal and Average Overview Tuesday, October 8, 2019 (Section 1 Tu/Th) Wednesday, October 9, 2019 (Section 2 M/W) Today we continue with setting up the second stage of the firm’s problem, the cost-minimization problem, where firms choose inputs \((l,k)\) that minimize total cost \((wl+rk)\) in order to produce the optimal amount of output \(q^*\).

item.title: 2.2 Short Run and Long Run - Readings
item.description: Recommended Ch. 6.2-6.4 in Austan Goolsbee, Steven Levitt, and Chad SyversonMicroeconomics, 2nd ed. (USA: Worth Publishers, 2012).

item.title: 2.3 Cost Minimization - Class Notes
item.description: Contents Overview Slides Practice Problems Appendix A Change in Relative Factor Prices Improvements in Technology Overview Thursday, March 5, 2020 Today we put our tools together (production functions/isoquants and isocost lines) to solve the firm’s cost minimization problem. Again, we do not solve this constrained optimization problem with calculus, but by looking graphically, and using an algabraic rule that should make intuitive sense.

item.title: 2.3 Cost Minimization - Practice Problems
item.description: Download as PDF Answer Key Your firm can use labor \(l\) and capital \(k\) to produce output according to the production function: \[q=4lk\] The marginal products are: \[\begin{align*} MP_l &=4k \\ MP_k &=4l \\ \end{align*}\] Suppose you need to produce 144 units, the price of labor is $10, and the price of capital is $40. 1. What is the least-cost combination of labor and capital that produces 144 units of output?

item.title: 2.3 Cost Minimization - Readings
item.description: Recommended Ch. 6.4-6.7 in Austan Goolsbee, Steven Levitt, and Chad SyversonMicroeconomics, 2nd ed. (USA: Worth Publishers, 2012).

item.title: 2.4 Cost and Revenue Functions - Readings
item.description: Recommended Ch. 7 in Austan Goolsbee, Steven Levitt, and Chad SyversonMicroeconomics, 2nd ed. (USA: Worth Publishers, 2012).

item.title: 2.4 Costs of Production - Class Notes
item.description: Contents Overview Class Livestream/Lecture Videos Slides Assignments: Exam 1 Corrections & Homework 3 Appendix The Relationship Between Returns to Scale and Costs Cobb-Douglas Cost Functions Tuesday, March 23, 2020 Quarantine Lecture 1 Overview Today we cover costs and revenues before we put them together next class to solve the firm’s profit maximization problem. Class Livestream/Lecture Videos See the above video for a brief overview of Zoom.

item.title: 2.5 Short Run Profit Maximization - Practice Problems
item.description: Download as PDF Answer Key A firm has short-run costs given by: \[\begin{align*} C(q)&=q^2+1\\ MC(q)&=2q\\ \end{align*}\] 1. Write an equation for fixed costs, \(f\). 2. Write an equation for variable costs, \(VC(q)\). 3. Write an equation for average fixed costs, \(AFC(q)\). 4. Write an equation for average variable costs, \(AVC(q)\). 5. Write an equation for average (total) costs, \(AC(q)\). 6. Suppose the firm is in a competitive market, and the current market price is $4, how many units of output maximize profits?

item.title: 2.5 Short Run Profit Maximization - Readings
item.description: Recommended Ch. 8.1-8.3 in Austan Goolsbee, Steven Levitt, and Chad SyversonMicroeconomics, 2nd ed. (USA: Worth Publishers, 2012).

item.title: 2.5: Short Run Profit Maximization - Class Notes
item.description: Contents Overview Class Livestream/Lecture Videos Slides Practice Problems Assignments: Exam 1 Corrections, Homework 3, Homework 4 Overview Thursday, March 25, 2020 Quarantine Lecture 2 Today we finish up costs from last lecture, and discuss revenues before we put them together next class to solve the firm’s profit maximization problem. We focus on the short run, where the firm incurs fixed costs and must stay in the market regardless.

item.title: 2.6: Long Run Industry Equilibrium - Class Notes
item.description: Contents Overview Class Livestream/Lecture Videos Slides Practice Assignments: HW 4 and Exam 2 Midterm Course Grades, and Exam 1 Corrections Appendix Cut for time: External Economies Cut for time: Factor Markets Overview Tuesday, March 31, 2020 Quarantine Lecture 3 We wrap up Unit 2 on Producers today, by bringing our optimization model of how firms maximize profits into the long run, when firms can enter or exit depending on profitability.

item.title: 2.6: Long Run Industry Equilibrium - Readings
item.description: Recommended Ch. 8.4-8.5, 2.5 in Austan Goolsbee, Steven Levitt, and Chad SyversonMicroeconomics, 2nd ed. (USA: Worth Publishers, 2012). See Ch. 2.5 for elasticity of supply.

item.title: 3.1: The Supply and Demand Model - Class Notes
item.description: Contents Overview Class Livestream/Lecture Videos Slides Assignments: HW 4 and Exam 2 Overview Thursday, April 2, 2020 Quarantine Lecture 4 Class Livestream/Lecture Videos Slides Lecture Slides Assignments: HW 4 and Exam 2 Homework 4 is due 11:59PM Sunday April 5 by email. Please attach your document as a PDF! Answers will be posted Monday morning. Exam 2 information, including practice exams, and a concept revie wguide is available.

item.title: 3.1: The Supply and Demand Model - Readings
item.description: Recommended Ch. 3 in Austan Goolsbee, Steven Levitt, and Chad SyversonMicroeconomics, 2nd ed. (USA: Worth Publishers, 2012).

item.title: 3.2: Market Competition and Surpluses - Class Notes
item.description: Contents Overview Class Livestream/Lecture Videos Slides Practice Interactive Examples Assignments: Exam 2 Overview Tuesday, April 7, 2020 Quarantine Lecture 5 Class Livestream/Lecture Videos Slides Lecture Slides Practice Today we will be working on a practice problem. Answers are posted on that page. Interactive Examples Visualizing the Elasticity and Surpluses Visualizing the Economic Incidence of Taxation These are examples that I wrote in R/Shiny in the past, to visualize what it is we are looking at.

item.title: 3.2: Market Competition and Surpluses - Practice Problems
item.description: Download as PDF Answer Key The supply and demand in the market for tomatoes are estimated to be: \[\begin{align*} q_D&=1000-200p\\ q_S&=200p-200\\ \end{align*}\] 1. Calculate the market-clearing price and quantity exchanged. 2. Find the inverse demand function and inverse supply function. 3. Sketch a graph of this market, labelling key points. 4. Calculate the price elasticty of demand and price elasticity of supply (in equilibrium).

item.title: 3.2: Market Competition and Surpluses - Readings
item.description: Recommended Chs. 2, 3.1 in Austan Goolsbee, Steven Levitt, and Chad SyversonMicroeconomics, 2nd ed. (USA: Worth Publishers, 2012).

item.title: 3.3 The Social Functions of Market Prices - Readings
item.description: Highly Recommended NPR Planet Money 665: “The Pickle Problem” NPR Planet Money 599: “The Invisible Wall” Hayek (1945), “The Use of Knowledge in Society” Alchian (1950), “Uncertainty, Evolution, and Economic Theory” “What if There Were No Prices?” “Mises vs. Marx: The March of History Rap Battle”

item.title: 3.3: The Social Functions of Market Prices - Class Notes
item.description: Contents Overview Class Livestream/Lecture Videos Slides Assignments: Exam 2 and Homework 5 Overview Thursday, April 9, 2020 Quarantine Lecture 6 Class Livestream/Lecture Videos Slides Lecture Slides Assignments: Exam 2 and Homework 5 Exam 2 is available to take on Blackboard until Sunday April 12 at 10:00PM. Once you open the exam, you have 2 hours to complete it on Blackboard.

item.title: 4.1 Monopoly - Readings
item.description: Recommended Ch. 9-2-9.5 in Austan Goolsbee, Steven Levitt, and Chad SyversonMicroeconomics, 2nd ed. (USA: Worth Publishers, 2012). Relevant classes from my Spring 2020 Industrial Organization course: 4.2 Antitrust I: The Law 4.3 Antitrust II: The Paradox 4.4 Antitrust III: Big Tech & Hipster Antitrust

item.title: 4.1: Monopoly - Class Notes
item.description: Contents Overview Class Livestream/Videos Slides Practice Problems Exam 2 Corrections Problem Set 5 Due 11:59PM Sunday April 19 Appendix Monopolists Only Produce Where Demand is Elastic: Proof Derivation of the Lerner Index Overview Tuesday, April 14, 2020 Quarantine Lecture 7 Today we begin our look at market power, when firms can charge \(p>MC\) and can search for the profit-maximizing quantity and price. We begin with our first extreme case of a single firm, a monopoly.

item.title: 4.1: Monopoly - Practice Problems
item.description: Download as PDF Answer Key Bob’s Bats produces baseball bats, and has the following costs: \[\begin{align*} C(q)&=5q^2+720\\ MC(q)&=10q\\ \end{align*}\] and faces a market demand for bats: \[q = 120-0.4p\] where quantity is measured in thousands of bats 1. Write Bob’s Marginal Revenue function. 2. Find the profit-maximizing quantity and price. 3. How much total profit does Bob’s Bats earn? Should Bob stay or exit this industry in the long run?

item.title: 4.2 Consequences and Sources of Market Power - Readings
item.description:
Recommended Ch. 9-1 in Austan Goolsbee, Steven Levitt, and Chad SyversonMicroeconomics, 2nd ed. (USA: Worth Publishers, 2012).
Tullock (1967), “The Welfare Cost of Tariffs, Monopolies, and Theft” Kreuger (1974), “The Political Economy of the Rent-Seeking Society” Mitchell (2012), “The Pathology of Privilege” Theil (2014), “Competition is for Losers” NPR Planet Money 599: “Why its Illegal to Braid Hair without a License”

item.title: 4.2: Consequences and Sources of Market Power - Class Notes
item.description: Contents Overview Class Livestream/Videos Slides Problem Set 5 Due 11:59PM Sunday April 19 Overview Thursday, April 16, 2020 Quarantine Lecture 8 Today we continue our look at market power, by looking at the social consequences of market power: deadweight loss, allocative inefficiency, and rent-seeking; as well as the primary causes: control over a key resource, barriers to entry, and economies of scale. Class Livestream/Videos Slides Lecture Slides Problem Set 5 Due 11:59PM Sunday April 19 Homework 5 on classes 3.

item.title: 4.3 Pricing With Market Power - Readings
item.description: Recommended Ch. 10.1-10.5 in Austan Goolsbee, Steven Levitt, and Chad SyversonMicroeconomics, 2nd ed. (USA: Worth Publishers, 2012).

item.title: 4.3: Pricing With Market Power - Class Notes
item.description: Contents Overview Class Livestream/Videos Slides Overview Tuesday, April 21, 2020 Quarantine Lecture 9 Class Livestream/Videos Slides Lecture Slides

item.title: 4.4 Monopolistic Competition & Monopoly - Readings
item.description:
Recommended Ch. 11 in Austan Goolsbee, Steven Levitt, and Chad SyversonMicroeconomics, 2nd ed. (USA: Worth Publishers, 2012).
NPR Planet Money: “The Raisin Outlaw” Relevant classes from my Spring 2020 Industrial Organization course: 4.2 Antitrust I: The Law 4.3 Antitrust II: The Paradox 4.4 Antitrust III: Big Tech & Hipster Antitrust

item.title: 4.4: Monopolistic Competition and Oligopoly - Class Notes
item.description: Contents Overview Class Livestream/Videos Slides Note on Assignments Appendix: More on Antitrust Overview Thursday, April 23, 2020 Quarantine Lecture 10 Class Livestream/Videos Slides Lecture Slides Note on Assignments Classes end Friday May 1. Please turn in all outstanding assignments (Exam 1 corrections, Exam 2 corrections, HW’s you may not have turned in) by then. The sooner you turn in your assignments, the sooner I can update your grades to be the most accurate on Blackboard.

item.title: Assignments
item.description: Grade Calculator Grade Calculator Use this tool to calculate your final course grade and predict what grades you would need on remaining assignments to obtain a desired course grade. Homeworks There will be roughly a homework assignment for every lesson. These questions will help check your understanding and mastery of the material, and will be a combination of quantitative, graph, and short answer questions of examples. These will also be good indicators of what to expect on the exams.

item.title: Class 2: Scarcity, Choice, and Cost
item.description: Contents Overview Slides Survey Overview Before we jump into our optimization models to descibe and predict (changes in) individual choices and behavior, we cover the basic principles of choice and action in a world of scarcity. This is what motivates economics. Slides Lecture Slides Survey

item.title: Exam 1 Information
item.description: Exam 1 is Tuesday, February 25, 2020 If you have any approved testing accomodations, or know you will be absent for the exam, please let me know ASAP. Concepts Study Guide Download PDF “Practice” Exam Download Old Exam 1 Old Exam 1 Answer Key Above, you have a previous semester’s actual exam. Use it to get a sense of what questions are asked, the format, and how many.

item.title: Exam 2 Information
item.description:
Exam 2 will be available 8:00 AM Tuesday, April 7 through 10:00 PM Sunday April 12 on BlackboardGo to our class Blackboard page, on the blue navigation bar on the left, click Assignments, you will find Exam 2.
Exam Instructions (IMPORTANT, PLEASE READ) This test will be available on Blackboard as a timed assignment. You will have 2 hours once you open the test on Blackboard. You will not need the whole time, I have given you some extra to accomodate the difficulties of taking an exam at home.

item.title: Final Exam Information
item.description:
Exam 2 will be available 8:00 AM Monday, May 4 through 11:59 PM Friday, May 8 on BlackboardGo to our class Blackboard page, on the blue navigation bar on the left, click Assignments, you will find the Final Exam.
Exam Instructions (IMPORTANT, PLEASE READ) This test will be available on Blackboard as a timed assignment. You will have 3 hours once you open the test on Blackboard. You will not need the whole time, I have given you some extra to accomodate the difficulties of taking an exam at home.

item.title: Opinion-Editorial Assignment
item.description: Due by 11:59 PM Friday May 1, by email (with a word count) How to Write a Good Paper See examples of good student Op-eds on Blackboard (Course Documents) “How can I know what I think until I see what I say?” — E. M. Forster on Writing Overview Your task is to write an Opinion-Editorial (Op-ed) piece that applies the economic way of thinking to some public policy-relevant issue.

item.title: Preliminary Survey on Math Background
item.description: Due by Tuesday, January 21, 2019 Download as PDF Answer Key This is an ungraded and anonymous survey for me to evaluate the distribution of your math and statistics backgrounds. Please write your answers the the following questions on a piece of paper, or download and print a PDF copy (link above) to write on. You do not need to write your name on it. Please complete all problems to the best of your ability.

item.title: Problem Set 1
item.description: Due by Thursday, February 13, 2020 Download as PDF Answer Key Please write your answers to the following questions on a piece of paper, or download and print a PDF copy (link above) to write on. You may also type your answers and print out a hard copy. You may work together (and I highly encourage that) but you must turn in your own answers.

item.title: Problem Set 2
item.description: Due by Thursday, February 20, 2020 Download as PDF Answer Key Please write your answers to the following questions on a piece of paper, or download and print a PDF copy (link above) to write on. You may also type your answers and print out a hard copy. You may work together (and I highly encourage that) but you must turn in your own answers. Your TA, under my supervision, will grade homeworks 70% for completion, and for the remaining 30%, pick one question to grade for accuracy - so it is best that you try every problem, even if you are unsure how to complete it accurately.

item.title: Problem Set 3
item.description: Due by 11:59 PM Sunday, March 29, 2020 by email Download as PDF Answer Key Updated Instructions for Online Course (Please Read!) Please type your answers to the following questions in a document and email it (as MS Word, PDF, etc) to me. You may still handwrite answers if you will be able to scan and email them if they are easily readable, but this is not preferred.

item.title: Problem Set 4
item.description: Due by 11:59 PM Sunday, April 5, 2020 by email Download as PDF Answer Key Updated Instructions for Online Course (Please Read!) Please type your answers to the following questions in a document and email a PDF attachment to me.In MS Word, or Pages, or most word processing software, File -> Save As -> PDF, or File -> Export -> PDF. You may still handwrite answers if you will be able to scan and email them, as a PDF, if they are easily readable, but this is not preferred.

item.title: Problem Set 5
item.description: Due by 11:59 PM Sunday, April 19, 2020 by email Download as PDF Answer Key Updated Instructions for Online Course (Please Read!) Please type your answers to the following questions in a document and email a PDF attachment to me.In MS Word, or Pages, or most word processing software, File -> Save As -> PDF, or File -> Export -> PDF. You may still handwrite answers if you will be able to scan and email them, as a PDF, if they are easily readable, but this is not preferred.

item.title: Problem Set 6
item.description: UNGRADED: For final exam practice only! Download as PDF Answer Key Concepts and Critical Thinking Please answer the following questions briefly (1-3 sentences). Use examples as necessary. Be sure to label graphs fully, if appropriate. Question 1 Compare and contrast the features of perfect competition monopoly oligopoly monopolistic competition Rank each market structure (from smallest to largest) in terms of

item.title: Reference
item.description: Contents Tips for Success Math Review List of Math Appendices Interactive Examples Look here over the course of the semester for resources, links, and tips on how to succeed in the course, how to write well, and other things of interest related to microeconomics. Tips for Success Take notes. On paper. Yes. Studies show that using pen and paper trump taking notes on a device. The main reason is because you cannot possibly write down everything I am saying by hand.

item.title: Schedule
item.description: This page contains all of the following resources for each class meeting: Readings include textbook chapters and occasional journal articles Assignments are due by the beginning of class unless otherwise stated Class materials contain extra explanations, math/statistical properties & proofs, and other helpful resourcesThese “online appendices” keep the slides nice and de-cluttered! Slides are “Xaringan” presentations in html that can be opened in any browserFile > Print > Save as PDF if you wish to download them

item.title: Syllabus
item.description: Download as PDF Last Updated: January 20, 2019 “The curious task of economics is to demonstrate to men how little they really know about what they imagine they can design.” - F.A. Hayek, 1974 Economics Nobel Laureate Microeconomic Analysis⊕Instructor Dr. Ryan Safner 118 Rosenstock safner@hood.edu @ryansafner Office hours: MW 3:30–5:00PM Course TuTh January 15–May 8, 2020 11:30 AM–12:45 PM

item.title: Transition to Online Course For Spring 2020
item.description: Contents Overview Changes to Course Structure & Assignments Specific Changes for Current Assignments 1. Exam 1 Corrections 2. Homework 3 3. Resuming class Overview Welcome to online classes from quarantine! None of us signed up for this. Some of you may be dealing hardships at home and at work, and may be juggling many problems right now. It may be awkward and difficult for you to learn at home, and for me to teach from home.
